description:
Alces alces, commonly known as the moose, is a large member of the deer family (Cervidae) native to the northern regions of North America, Europe, and Asia. It is the largest living species of the deer family, with adult males (bulls) reaching up to 1.8 meters (5.9 feet) tall at the shoulder and weighing up to 700 kilograms (1,540 pounds).

The moose is characterized by its distinctive long legs, large, bulbous nose, and broad, palmate antlers that can span up to 1.8 meters (5.9 feet) in width. Its thick, dark brown or black fur provides insulation against the cold temperatures of its habitat, which includes boreal forests, swamps, and tundra regions.

Moose are herbivores, feeding primarily on aquatic vegetation, such as submerged and floating plants, as well as terrestrial vegetation, including twigs, leaves, and bark from various tree species. They are known for their impressive swimming abilities, which they use to access aquatic food sources and escape predators.

The moose plays a significant ecological role in its habitat, acting as a keystone species and influencing the composition and structure of the plant communities it inhabits. It is also an important game animal in many regions, and its meat and hide have been used by indigenous communities for subsistence and cultural purposes.
